marc:datafield.marc:subfield: John Houstoun was governor of Georgia and a jurist, from Savannah.

Papers include an order for the defense of Richmond County; a letter, 1784, from John Habersham discussing negotiations with Indian representatives concerning land purchases, and an incident between Georgia residents and Indians; a statement of dissent from the Boundary Commission concerning the boundary dispute between South Carolina and Georgia; a petition to adjourn court to allow jurors to put down an Indian attack, and miscellaneous land grants, indentures, and summonses.
W. C. Houston was professor of mathematics and natural philosophy at the College of New Jersey
Letter from W. C. Houston to James Ewing about raising troops, supplies, and money for the Revolutionary forces.
Placebo Houston was a captain of the North Carolina Rangers, from Houstonville (Iredell County), North Carolina.

Personal and family correspondence with relatives in Alabama, Mississippi, and Missouri, describing the climate and crops, social life and customs, prices of slaves and land, religion, and daily life. Included are several wills.
A. Houston was a government official in Grenada.

Letter from Houston to John Baird in Glasgow, reporting that Baird's holdings and property in Grenada are safe following the defeat of Fedon insurgents. Also includes some business advice about sugar sales, and comments regarding the lack of credit and his own hopes for peace.
Lucy Hamilton Hooper was an editor and journalist residing in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, and Paris, France.
Letter from Hooper concerning her plan to publish a compilation of selected writings by American poets.
Edmund Hoskins was a merchant of Edenton, Chowan County, North Carolina.
Business correspondence of a merchant including account sheets and two letters dealing with privateering during the War of 1812.
Daniel C. Hopkins was a resident of Edgecombe County, North Carolina.
Miscellaneous bills, receipts, indentures, and warrants, several of which deal with the hiring and wage scale of slaves.
Michael Houser was a resident of Stokes and Forsyth Counties, North Carolina.
Tax receipts, 1825-1839, land indentures, and bills and receipts of Michael Houser.
Samuel Houston was a general in the War of 1812, member of United States Congress, 1823-1825, governor of Tennessee, 1827-1829, president of Texas, and United States senator, 1846-1859.
Papers of Samuel Houston include a letter to John Taylor concerning Houston's trip toward Marlboro, South Carolina; and a land grant issued while governor of Tennessee.
William H. Horah was agent for the State Bank of North Carolina to 1834 and for the Bank of Cape Fear, 1834-1863.
Routine business letters to William H. Horah, dealing with the transfer of bills of exchange and other matters.
Edward Hopkins was a resident of Darien, Georgia.

Letter of Roger Lawson Gamble, United States representative from Georgia, 1833-1835 and 1841-1843, discussing rumors of the split in the president's cabinet and the effect it had had on holding up all appointments.
George Hosler was a resident of Rockingham County, Virginia.
Business letters addressed to George Hosler.
John Walter Hooper was a resident of Baltimore, Maryland.

The collection contains the letter of J. W. Hooper to his sister following the death of her daughter, Annie. There are also five letters to his wife written while Hooper was on a trip to Dorchester County.
Henry Howard was a resident of Floyd, Floyd County, Virginia.
Business letters to Henry Howard from S. R. Aldridge concerning personal debts.
O. O. Hoover was a New Philadelphia (Tuscarawas County), Ohio, resident.
Collection consists of a handwritten essay (3 pages) by Hoover on the Zoarite religious community in Zoar, Ohio.
Unprocessed collection. Cataloged from accession record.
Henry H. Hopkins was a military chaplain in the United States Army stationed at Alexandria, Virginia.

Civil War letters of Hopkins, including after his appointment as chaplain of the 120th Regiment of New York Volunteers, to Mary Ames and Winona C. Ames. Discusses conversion of Fairfax Seminary into a convalescent camp, the surrender of Harpers Ferry, the New York draft riots, the battle of Cold Harbor, the siege of Petersburg, family matters, and the building of a chapel.
U.S. Representative and Senator, of Detroit, Mich.
Notes and opinions of the four sections of the 14th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, formulated by the Joint Committee on Reconstruction, of which Howard was a member.
William Hooper was an instructor at Wilson Female Seminary (Wilson County, North Carolina).

Letters from William Hooper, who with his brothers, J.D. and Thomas C. Hooper, and R.F. Hunt, comprised the faculty of the Wilson Female Seminary, to Maria J. Beattie, a graduate of Edgeworth Seminary, Greensboro, North Carolina, concerning her qualifications for teaching in the Wilson Female Seminary; and a personal letter dealing with a family matter.
Edward Hoover was a farmer, of Franklin County, Pennsylvania.
Letters of Hoover giving detailed accounts of farm life, farming methods, prices of crops, and church activities, including revivals, love feasts, and preaching.
